docs.title: Hive Documentation
docs.text: Welcome to the Hive ecosystem documentation. This site provides comprehensive guides for HiveFabric, AgentFabric, and executor implementations.

docs.title: Quick Links
docs.text:
• Overview - Understand Hive, HiveFabric, and AgentFabric
  • AgentFabric Runtime - Build and run distributed agent tasks
  • Executors - Deploy on mobile, desktop, and cloud platforms
  • Architecture - System design and component interactions
  • FAQ - Common questions and troubleshooting

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: Choose your starting point: 1. New to Hive? Start with Overview 2. Building tasks? See AgentFabric Spec 3. Deploying agents? Check Executors 4. Want to integrate? Read SDK Documentation

docs.title: HiveFabric (Control Plane)
docs.text:
Task Router: Routes incoming task definitions to appropriate executors based on: - Required capabilities - Cost optimization - Load balancing - Fault tolerance

Scheduler: Manages task queuing and execution scheduling: - Priority queues per executor - Deadline tracking - Resource reservation - Retry logic

Marketplace: Matches tasks to agents: - Reputation scoring - Price negotiation - Availability checking - Matchmaking algorithm

State Store: Persistent storage for: - Task definitions and status - Executor registrations - Agent reputation data - Payment records

Event Stream: Real-time event bus: - Task progress updates - Executor status changes - Payment events - Audit trail

docs.title: Executors
docs.text: Each executor maintains: - Task Queue: Pending tasks for this executor - Sandbox Manager: Task isolation and resource control - Event Emitter: Real-time status updates - Result Validator: Cryptographic proof generation - Agent Interface: Marketplace and state reporting

docs.title: Task Execution Flow
docs.text:
1. Task Definition (YAML/JSON)
         │
         ▼
2. HiveFabric Validation
         │
         ▼
3. Marketplace Matching
         │
         ▼
4. Executor Assignment

5. Task Download & Validation

6. Sandbox Setup & Execution

docs.title: Event Stream
docs.text:
Events flow in real-time to task creators:

{
  "task_id": "abc123",
  "timestamp": "2026-02-01T10:00:00Z",
  "events": [
    {"type": "scheduled", "executor": "desktop-1"},
    {"type": "node_started", "node_id": "fetch"},
    {"type": "node_completed", "node_id": "fetch", "output": {...}},
    {"type": "node_started", "node_id": "process"},
    {"type": "task_completed", "result": {...}}
  ]
}

docs.title: Fault Tolerance
docs.text:
• Task Replay: Failed tasks resubmitted to different executor
  • Partial Results: Completed nodes cached to avoid re-execution
  • State Checkpointing: Executor periodically saves progress
  • Deadline Enforcement: Tasks with unmet deadlines fail explicitly

docs.title: Scalability
docs.text:
• Horizontal executor scaling (add more executors)
  • Marketplace manages supply/demand
  • Event streaming handles real-time coordination
  • Sharded state store for large deployments

See Executors and AgentFabric Runtime for implementation details.

docs.title: What's the difference between Hive and other distributed systems?
docs.text: Hive focuses on agent participation in distributed computation. Unlike centralized cloud systems, Hive enables individuals and organizations to contribute computational resources to a marketplace, earning rewards while maintaining security and autonomy.

docs.title: Can I run Hive on my personal device?
docs.text: Yes. Executors are available for Android, iOS, Windows, Linux, and macOS. You can join the marketplace and earn by participating.

docs.title: Is there a minimum task complexity?
docs.text: No. Tasks can be simple (single step) or complex (multi-step DAGs with parallel branches). The runtime automatically optimizes execution.

docs.title: What languages can I use in tasks?
docs.text: Tasks are platform-agnostic. You can invoke: - Native binaries (compiled languages) - Scripted languages (Python, JavaScript, etc.) - Containerized applications - HTTP APIs

docs.title: How do I debug task failures?
docs.text:
1. Check execution logs: hive-executor logs --task-id <id>
  2. Review event stream for node-level errors
  3. Test locally before marketplace submission
  4. Use structured error handling in DAG definitions

docs.title: Can tasks communicate across executors?
docs.text: No, by design. Each node runs independently. Communication happens through input parameters and output results, creating implicit ordering through DAG structure.

docs.title: What happens if an executor crashes mid-task?
docs.text: HiveFabric detects the failure (heartbeat timeout) and reassigns to another executor. Already-completed nodes aren't re-executed; only failed nodes are retried.

docs.title: How is pricing determined?
docs.text: Task creators specify maximum budget. Agents bid on tasks. Competition drives prices toward marginal cost. HiveFabric selects the cheapest available agent.

docs.title: What prevents cheating?
docs.text:
• Cryptographic validation: Results are signed and verified
  • Spot checking: Random tasks re-executed by different executors
  • Reputation system: Dishonest agents lose access
  • Slashing: Deposit loss for misbehavior

docs.title: Can I get paid immediately?
docs.text: Payments settle after task completion and validation (typically within minutes). Agents can withdraw to blockchain or traditional payment methods.

docs.title: How are my tasks kept private?
docs.text:
• Tasks are encrypted in transit
  • Results visible only to task creator
  • Executor sandboxes prevent side-channel access
  • Audit logs track all access

docs.title: Can executors see my task input/output?
docs.text: Executors see the data they need to run your task. You should: - Avoid embedding secrets in task definitions - Use secure credential management - Implement data obfuscation if needed

docs.title: Is the system quantum-resistant?
docs.text: Current implementation uses RSA-3072 and ECDSA. Quantum-safe algorithms are on the roadmap.

docs.title: How long do tasks take to start?
docs.text: Average: 2-5 seconds from submission to execution start. Includes HiveFabric routing, executor pickup, and sandbox setup.

docs.title: Can I set timeouts?
docs.text:
Yes, per-node and per-task timeouts are configurable:

nodes:
  - id: "fetch"
    timeout_seconds: 300  # 5 minute timeout

docs.title: How do I optimize for cost?
docs.text:
• Use fewer parallel branches (reduces executor count)
  • Request only necessary resources
  • Prefer high-reputation, lower-cost executors
  • Batch similar tasks for amortized overhead

docs.title: Support
docs.text: For more help: - Check Architecture for system design - Review Examples for patterns - File an issue on GitHub - Contact support@hive.io

docs.title: Marketplace & Agent Economics
docs.text: The Hive marketplace enables trustless exchange of computational services.

docs.title: Agents (Sellers)
docs.text: Agents contribute computational capacity: - Mobile devices and desktops - Desktop machines with spare capacity - Cloud infrastructure operators

docs.title: Tasks (Buyers)
docs.text: Task creators submit work to the marketplace: - Data processing jobs - ML training tasks - Multi-step workflows

docs.title: Economics
docs.text: Pricing Model: Pay-per-execution - Task creator specifies budget: max_price_per_second - Agents bid on tasks - Lowest-cost available agent wins - Payment occurs upon successful completion

docs.title: Agent Reputation Score
docs.text: Based on: - Task completion rate - Execution time accuracy - Result quality (spot checks) - Audit compliance - User feedback

docs.title: Task Deposit
docs.text: Task creators provide security deposit to: - Ensure timely payment - Discourage cancellations - Cover arbitration costs

docs.title: Matchmaking
docs.text: HiveFabric matches tasks to agents based on: - Cost (minimize total payment) - Capability match (agent can run task) - Geographic proximity (reduce latency) - Agent reputation and availability - Network topology

docs.title: Payment & Settlement
docs.text:
1. Task creator deposits funds
  2. Task is executed
  3. Results are validated (cryptographic proof)
  4. Payment released to agent
  5. Excess deposit returned to task creator

docs.title: Dispute Resolution
docs.text: Arbitration: - 3rd-party validators re-execute tasks - Deterministic results validated - Honest party compensated - Dishonest party penalized (loss of reputation + deposit)

docs.title: Anti-Sybil Measures
docs.text:
• Identity verification (for high-value tasks)
  • Gradual reputation unlock for new agents
  • Rate limiting on task submissions
  • Proof-of-work for computational tasks

docs.title: What is Hive?
docs.text:
Hive is a distributed execution platform designed for complex, multi-step agent workflows. It enables organizations to:

  • Define agent tasks as composable, fork-join DAGs
  • Execute tasks across heterogeneous executors (mobile, desktop, cloud)
  • Manage agent economics through a marketplace model
  • Ensure security and resource control across execution boundaries

docs.title: HiveFabric
docs.text: The control plane and orchestration layer that: - Accepts task definitions (YAML/JSON) - Manages execution scheduling and state - Coordinates with multiple executors - Handles authentication and authorization

docs.title: AgentFabric Runtime
docs.text: The task execution engine that: - Interprets fork-join DAG specifications - Manages parallel and sequential task execution - Provides SDK/APIs for task composition - Emits execution events and telemetry

docs.title: Executors
docs.text: Worker nodes that execute tasks: - Mobile: Android and iOS devices - Desktop: Windows, Linux, macOS machines - Cloud: Containerized environments

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
• Multi-step AI workflows with human-in-the-loop steps
  • Distributed data processing pipelines
  • Agent orchestration across device networks
  • Marketplace-based computation

See Architecture for system design details.

docs.title: AgentFabric Runtime
docs.text: AgentFabric is the execution engine for Hive tasks. It interprets fork-join directed acyclic graphs (DAGs) and orchestrates parallel and sequential execution.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Fork-Join DAGs: Define complex workflows with parallel branches
  • YAML/JSON Support: Define tasks in human-readable formats
  • SDK/API Integration: Programmatic task composition
  • Event-Driven: Stream execution events for monitoring and debugging
  • Multi-Language: Execute tasks across different runtime environments

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text:
• Specification - DAG format, runtime semantics, and execution model
  • SDK/API - Programmatic interfaces and libraries
  • Examples - Sample tasks and real-world DAG patterns

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
1. Read the Specification to understand DAG structure
  2. Review Examples for common patterns
  3. Use the SDK to build your first task

docs.title: Example 1: Electricity Tariff Checker (Simple DAG)
docs.text:
Agent Type: electricity-tariff-checker Executor Target: Mobile / Desktop

Agent Bundle Structure:

agent-bundle/
├─ agent.yaml
├─ wasm/
│   ├─ fetch-tariffs.wasm
│   └─ push-notify.wasm
├─ assets/
└─ signature.sig

docs.title: Agent YAML (bundle):
docs.text:
agent:
  id: "agent-uuid-1234"
  name: "Electricity Tariff Checker"
  version: "0.1"
  runtime: "AgentFabric v0.1"
  schedule:
    type: cron
    value: "0 9 * * *"
  tasks:
    - task_id: "fetch-tariffs"
      image: "wasm/fetch-tariffs:v0.1"
      inputs:
        location: "{{user_config.location}}"
      outputs: ["tariffs.json"]
      resources:
        cpu: 1
        memory: 128MB
      fork_join: false
    - task_id: "notify-user"
      image: "wasm/push-notify:v0.1"
      dependencies: ["fetch-tariffs"]
      fork_join: false

docs.title: User Instance Example:
docs.text:
agent_id: "user-agent-uuid-9876"
schema_type: "electricity-tariff-checker"
schema_version: "1.0"
user_config:
  location: "ES-Madrid"
  notification_type: "email"
  check_frequency: "0 8 * * *"
  price_threshold: 0.15
resources:
  cpu: 1
  memory: 128MB
fork_join: false

docs.title: Example 2: Multi-Task Weather + Electricity Agent (Fork-Join DAG)
docs.text: Scenario: Combine weather and electricity price checks; notify only if conditions meet criteria.

docs.title: Agent YAML (bundle):
docs.text:
agent:
  id: "agent-uuid-5678"
  name: "Weather + Tariff Checker"
  version: "0.1"
  runtime: "AgentFabric v0.1"
  schedule:
    type: cron
    value: "0 7 * * *"
  tasks:
    - task_id: "fetch-weather"
      image: "wasm/fetch-weather:v0.1"
      inputs:
        city: "{{user_config.city}}"
      outputs: ["weather.json"]
      resources:
        cpu: 1
        memory: 64MB
      fork_join: true
    - task_id: "fetch-tariffs"
      image: "wasm/fetch-tariffs:v0.1"
      inputs:
        location: "{{user_config.location}}"
      outputs: ["tariffs.json"]
      resources:
        cpu: 1
        memory: 128MB
      fork_join: true
    - task_id: "notify-user"
      image: "wasm/push-notify:v0.1"
      dependencies: ["fetch-weather", "fetch-tariffs"]
      fork_join: false

docs.title: User Instance Example:
docs.text:
agent_id: "user-agent-uuid-2345"
schema_type: "weather-tariff-checker"
schema_version: "0.1"
user_config:
  city: "ES-Madrid"

✅ This shows fork-join in action: two tasks run in parallel, results joined for notification.

docs.title: Example 3: Desktop Executor Task
docs.text: Scenario: Heavy data processing that cannot run on mobile.

docs.title: Agent YAML (bundle):
docs.text:
agent:
  id: "agent-uuid-9012"
  name: "Large CSV Processor"
  version: "0.1"
  runtime: "AgentFabric v0.1"
  schedule:
    type: interval
    value: "3600" # every hour
  tasks:
    - task_id: "download-csv"
      image: "docker/csv-downloader:v0.1"
      inputs:
        url: "{{user_config.csv_url}}"
      outputs: ["data.csv"]
      resources:
        cpu: 1
        memory: 256MB
    - task_id: "process-csv"
      image: "docker/csv-processor:v0.1"
      dependencies: ["download-csv"]
      outputs: ["results.json"]
      resources:
        cpu: 4
        memory: 1GB

docs.title: User Instance Example:
docs.text:
agent_id: "user-agent-uuid-5678"
schema_type: "csv-processor"
schema_version: "0.1"
user_config:
  csv_url: "https://example.com/data.csv"
resources:
  cpu: 4
  memory: 1GB
fork_join: false

Desktop executor handles higher CPU and memory, mobile skipped for this agent.

docs.title: 4️⃣ Example 4: Marketplace-Ready Agent
docs.text:
Scenario: Public agent for everyone in the Hive app marketplace.

agent_schema:
  type: "daily-news-notifier"
  version: "1.0"
  description: "Fetches top news headlines and sends daily notifications"
  parameters:
    topics:
      type: enum
      enum: ["tech", "finance", "sports", "world"]
      default: ["tech"]
    notification_type:
      type: enum
      enum: ["push", "email"]
      default: "push"
  resources:
    cpu: 1
    memory: 64MB
  fork_join: false
  schedule:
    type: cron
    value: "0 8 * * *"
  marketplace:
    public: true
    credits_required: 5

docs.title: User Instance Example:
docs.text:
agent_id: "user-agent-uuid-9999"
schema_type: "daily-news-notifier"
schema_version: "1.0"
user_config:
  topics: ["finance", "tech"]
  notification_type: "email"
resources:
  cpu: 1
  memory: 64MB
fork_join: false

This example demonstrates a marketplace agent that anyone can select and customize.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
{{user_config.*}} placeholders are replaced at runtime with user-defined values.

Executors validate agent schema before executing tasks.

Fork-join DAG execution allows parallelism with dependencies.

All examples are cross-platform, adjusted for mobile, desktop, or cloud resources.

Marketplace metadata supports credits/tokens, public/private agents, and versioning.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The AgentFabric SDK provides programmatic APIs for task composition, submission, and monitoring.

docs.title: Python SDK
docs.text:
from agentfabric import Task, Fork, Step

# Define a task
task = Task(name="my-workflow")

# Add sequential steps
task.add_step(Step(
    id="fetch",
    action="fetch_data",
    params={"source": "api"}
))

# Add parallel branches
fork = Fork(id="parallel-processing", join_strategy="all")
fork.add_child(Step(id="process-a", action="process", params={"variant": "a"}))
fork.add_child(Step(id="process-b", action="process", params={"variant": "b"}))
task.add_node(fork)

# Submit task
result = task.submit(executor="auto")

docs.title: REST API
docs.text:
POST /api/v1/tasks
{
  "definition": {...}
}

GET /api/v1/tasks/{task_id}
GET /api/v1/tasks/{task_id}/events

docs.title: Event Streaming
docs.text:
Monitor task execution in real-time:

task = Task.get(task_id)
for event in task.stream_events():
    print(f"Node {event.node_id}: {event.status}")

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
try:
    result = task.submit()
except TaskError as e:
    print(f"Task failed: {e.node_id} - {e.message}")

See Examples for integration patterns.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The AgentFabric runtime executes fork-join DAGs (Directed Acyclic Graphs) that define multi-step agent workflows.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
AgentFabric is a lightweight, cross-platform runtime for autonomous agents that allows tasks to:

Run in sandboxed containers (mobile, desktop, cloud)

Be scheduled as fork-join DAGs for parallelism and dependency management

Report results back to HiveFabric with audit logs

Earn credits/tokens when executed on user devices

docs.title: Agent Definition
docs.text:
An Agent is a self-contained unit of work with:

  • Metadata
  • Execution rules
  • Fork-join DAG tasks
  • Runtime resource requirements

docs.title: Example Agent Definition
docs.text:
agent:
  id: "agent-uuid-1234"
  name: "Electricity Tariff Checker"
  version: "0.1"
  author: "user123"
  description: "Checks best electricity tariffs daily and sends notification"
  runtime: "AgentFabric v0.1"
  schedule:
    type: "cron"
    value: "0 9 * * *"
  tasks:
    - task_id: "fetch-tariffs"
      image: "wasm/fetch-tariffs:v0.1"
      inputs:
        location: "ES-Vigo"
      outputs: ["tariffs.json"]
      resources:
        cpu: 1
        memory: 128MB
      fork_join: false
    - task_id: "notify-user"
      image: "wasm/push-notify:v0.1"
      dependencies: ["fetch-tariffs"]
      fork_join: false

docs.title: Agent Schema Definition
docs.text: Agent Schemas define agent types and configurable parameters for users.

docs.title: agent-schema.yaml
docs.text:
$schema: "https://yaml-schema.org/draft-07/schema#"
title: "HiveFabric Agent Schema"
description: "Defines agent types, parameters, resources, and marketplace metadata for HiveFabric."
type: object
required:
  - type
  - version
  - parameters
properties:
  type:
    type: string
    description: "Unique identifier for the agent type"
  version:
    type: string
    description: "Semantic version of the agent schema"
  description:
    type: string
    description: "Human-readable description of the agent type"
  parameters:
    type: object
    description: "User-configurable parameters for this agent type"
    additionalProperties: false
    patternProperties:
      ".*":
        type: object
        required: ["type"]
        properties:
          type:
            type: string
            enum: ["string", "number", "boolean", "enum"]
          description:
            type: string
          default:
            type: any
          enum:
            type: array
            items:
              type: string
  resources:
    type: object
    required: ["cpu", "memory"]
    properties:
      cpu:
        type: number
      memory:
        type: string
  fork_join:
    type: boolean
    default: false
  schedule:
    type: object
    properties:
      type:
        type: string
        enum: ["cron", "interval", "manual"]
      value:
        type: string
  marketplace:
    type: object
    properties:
      public:
        type: boolean
        default: true
      credits_required:
        type: number
        default: 10

docs.title: Example Agent Type
docs.text:
type: "electricity-tariff-checker"
version: "1.0"
description: "Checks best electricity tariffs and sends notifications"
parameters:
  location:
    type: string
    description: "City or region for electricity tariffs"
    default: "ES-Vigo"
  notification_type:
    type: enum
    description: "Notification method"
    enum: ["push", "email", "sms"]
    default: "push"
  check_frequency:
    type: string
    description: "Cron expression for agent execution"
    default: "0 9 * * *"
  price_threshold:
    type: number
    description: "Only notify if tariff is below this value"
    default: 0.20
resources:
  cpu: 1
  memory: 128MB
fork_join: false
schedule:
  type: cron
  value: "0 9 * * *"
marketplace:
  public: true
  credits_required: 10

docs.title: Example Agent Instance (User Configured)
docs.text:
agent_id: "user-agent-uuid-9876"
schema_type: "electricity-tariff-checker"
schema_version: "1.0"
user_config:
  location: "ES-Madrid"
  notification_type: "email"
  check_frequency: "0 8 * * *"
  price_threshold: 0.15
resources:
  cpu: 1
  memory: 128MB
fork_join: false

HiveFabric validates the user_config against the schema

Executor runs tasks using user_config values

docs.title: Task Lifecycle
docs.text:
Scheduled / Triggered – HiveFabric assigns task to executor

Fetch / Prepare – Executor downloads and validates agent bundle

Execute – Sandbox execution (WASM, container)

Fork-Join Handling – Wait for dependencies if required

Report – Output results + logs back to HiveFabric

Credit / Token Accounting – Executor earns proportional tokens

docs.title: Executor Interfaces
docs.text:
Mobile (Android / iOS)

Runs inside app sandbox

Resource throttling to avoid battery drain

Limited CPU/memory

Auto-updates runtime via HiveFabric

Desktop / Server (Windows / Linux / macOS)

Background service / daemon

Full CPU/memory access (configurable)

Uses WASM sandbox or lightweight container

Auto-updates via HiveFabric

docs.title: Security & Isolation
docs.text:
Executors have unique keypairs for authentication

Agent bundles are signed by HiveFabric

Resource limits enforced per task

Execution logs are tamper-evident and auditable

Enterprise isolation optional (private executor pools, private DAGs)

docs.title: Scheduler / Fork-Join Model
docs.text:
Tasks organized in DAGs

Executors pick ready-to-run tasks

Fork-join ensures parallel execution when possible, joins when required

HiveFabric handles load balancing across heterogeneous nodes

docs.title: Marketplace & Credit System
docs.text:
Executors earn credits proportional to CPU/memory usage

Users spend credits to run their agents or access premium marketplace agents

HiveFabric retains a fraction for profit

Enterprise agreements support private deployments

docs.title: File / Module Structure
docs.text:
agent-bundle/
├─ agent.yaml           # Metadata + DAG
├─ wasm/                # WASM modules or containers
│   ├─ fetch-tariffs.wasm
│   └─ push-notify.wasm
├─ assets/              # Optional static assets
└─ signature.sig        # Signed bundle hash

docs.title: Executors
docs.text: Executors are worker nodes that execute AgentFabric tasks. Hive supports executors across multiple platforms.

docs.title: Executor Types
docs.text:
• Mobile - Android and iOS devices
  • Desktop - Windows, Linux, macOS machines
  • Cloud - Containerized and managed services

docs.title: Registration
docs.text: Executors register with HiveFabric and advertise capabilities: - Platform (mobile, desktop, cloud) - Resource constraints (CPU, memory, storage) - Supported actions - Security posture

docs.title: Task Acceptance
docs.text: An executor: 1. Receives a task assignment from HiveFabric 2. Validates resource requirements 3. Executes the task in a sandboxed environment 4. Streams execution events back 5. Reports completion or failure

docs.title: Security & Isolation
docs.text:
All executors enforce: - Sandboxing: Tasks run in isolated environments - Resource Control: CPU, memory, network limits - Audit Logging: All actions are logged - Authentication: Cryptographic verification of task origin

See Security for detailed isolation models.

docs.title: Desktop Executors
docs.text: Desktop executors run on Windows, Linux, and macOS machines.

docs.title: Linux
docs.text:
# Install from package manager or binary
curl -O https://releases.hive.io/executor/linux/hive-executor
chmod +x hive-executor
./hive-executor --install

docs.title: Windows
docs.text: Download installer from https://releases.hive.io/executor/windows/

docs.title: macOS
docs.text:
brew install hive-executor
hive-executor --install

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
# ~/.hive/config.yml
node_id: "desktop-1"
platform: "linux"
max_concurrent_tasks: 4
resources:
  cpu_cores: 4
  memory_gb: 16
  storage_gb: 100
actions:
  - name: "file_process"
    enabled: true
  - name: "compile"
    enabled: true

docs.title: Capabilities Advertisement
docs.text: Executors auto-detect: - OS and architecture - Available CPU cores - Disk space - Network connectivity - Installed runtimes (Python, Node.js, etc.)

docs.title: Task Execution
docs.text:
Tasks execute in isolated containers or VMs:

nodes:
  - id: "compute"
    type: "step"
    action: "run_script"
    params:
      script: "process_data.py"
      timeout: 3600

docs.title: Monitoring
docs.text:
hive-executor status
hive-executor logs --follow

docs.title: Mobile Executors
docs.text: Mobile executors allow Hive tasks to run on Android and iOS devices.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
# Install via APK or app store
adb install hive-executor.apk

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
<!-- hive-config.xml -->
<hive>
  <node_id>mobile-1</node_id>
  <platform>android</platform>
  <capabilities>
    <storage_mb>1024</storage_mb>
    <memory_mb>2048</memory_mb>
    <actions>
      <action name="camera_capture"/>
      <action name="sensor_read"/>
      <action name="process_image"/>
    </actions>
  </capabilities>
</hive>

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: Via App Store or TestFlight. See iOS app documentation.

docs.title: Permissions
docs.text:
Request required permissions in task definition:

nodes:
  - id: "capture"
    type: "step"
    action: "camera_capture"
    required_permissions:
      - "camera"
      - "location"

docs.title: Sensor Data Collection
docs.text:
nodes:
  - id: "read-sensors"
    type: "fork"
    join_strategy: "all"
    children:
      - id: "accelerometer"

      - id: "gps"

docs.title: Battery Awareness
docs.text: Mobile executors honor battery constraints. Tasks may be paused or scheduled during high-battery periods.

docs.title: Debugging
docs.text:
Check logs via:

adb logcat | grep hive

docs.title: Executor Security Model
docs.text: Hive implements defense-in-depth security for all executors.

docs.title: Container Isolation (Linux/Desktop)
docs.text:
Tasks run in Docker containers or VMs with: - Separate filesystem root - Network namespace isolation - Resource quotas (cgroups) - Read-only system files

# Example task container
FROM alpine:3.18
RUN apk add python3
COPY task.py /task/
WORKDIR /task
ENTRYPOINT ["python3", "task.py"]

docs.title: App Sandboxing (Mobile)
docs.text:
Android: - SELinux policies - Runtime permission model - App-specific storage isolation

iOS: - XPC services - App container restrictions - Entitlement-based access control

docs.title: Resource Control
docs.text:
All executors enforce limits:

tasks:
  cpu_limit: "2000m"
  memory_limit: "1Gi"
  disk_limit: "10Gi"
  network_egress_limit: "100Mb/s"
  timeout_seconds: 3600

docs.title: Audit Logging
docs.text:
Every task execution logs: - Task ID and definition - Executor node and timestamp - Input parameters - Output and exit status - Resource usage - Security events (permission denials, etc.)

{
  "timestamp": "2026-02-01T10:00:00Z",
  "task_id": "abc123",
  "executor": "desktop-1",
  "event": "task_completed",
  "resources_used": {
    "cpu_ms": 5000,
    "memory_peak_mb": 512,
    "disk_mb": 100
  }
}

docs.title: Cryptographic Verification
docs.text:
• Tasks are signed by HiveFabric
  • Executors verify signatures before execution
  • Results are signed by executors
  • Chain of custody maintained

docs.title: Best Practices for Task Authors
docs.text:
1. Request minimum necessary permissions
  2. Use resource constraints appropriate to your task
  3. Implement error handling gracefully
  4. Avoid hardcoding secrets; use secure credential stores
  5. Sanitize all external inputs
